data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Definition of Conflict
data.desc:
Positive: costitutive condition of living together. It's the result of the human plurality. It could be positive confront, structural antagonism that moves history. 

Negative: conflict as a consequence of power-resistance dynamics, and as the base of institutions.
links: Jean-Luc Nancy, Hanna Arendt, Marx, Nietzche, Foucault

data.title: Definition of Infrastructure
data.desc: Complementary works necessary for the performance of an activity (roads, railways, aqueducts, telecommunication networks, digital). They are the foundation of the main structure, necessary for the economic and social development of a country.

data.title: Physical Infrastructures
data.desc: Material and tangible components necessary for the functioning of society and the economy, including transportation systems (roads, railways, ports), essential services (energy, water, telecommunications), buildings, and, in the IT sector, data centers, servers, and networking equipment.

data.title: Technological and Digital Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of hardware, software, networks, and data centers that enable the management of digital data and resources, supporting the daily activities and growth strategies of organizations and society. Key elements include data centers, storage systems, networking equipment (routers and switches), cloud platforms, and data processing systems, making connectivity, security, and efficiency of digital processes possible.

data.title: Social Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of assets functional to meeting essential collective needs, particularly in the areas of education, healthcare, and housing.

data.title: Law & Order and Institutional Infrastructures
data.desc: Law & Order infrastructure refers to the systems, institutions, and resources that uphold public safety, enforce laws, and guarantee justice. It includes courts, police, prisons, and regulatory bodies, ensuring stability and protection of rights.

data.title: Economical and financial Infrastructures
data.desc: Economic and financial infrastructure refers to the set of institutions, markets, and systems that enable the functioning of the economy. It includes banks, stock exchanges, payment systems, insurance, and credit networks. These ensure the circulation of money, investment management, and the stability of transactions. Their efficiency is crucial for a country’s development and growth.

data.title: Cultural Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of material and immaterial elements (structures, spaces, technologies, communities, traditions, collections) that make up a territory’s cultural heritage and facilitate its enjoyment, development, and preservation, while promoting creativity and local identity.

data.title: Infrastructural conflict
data.desc: situation of contrast, opposition, and tension, that regards the project, localisation, realisation, management, resignation of an infrastructure (physical or immaterial).

data.title: First topics brainstorm
data.desc:
- Security cameras, big brother, conflict in surveillance
- Construction of Infrastructures that then self-damage
- Transport Infrastructures designed for AI, instead of humans 
- Bureaucracy (as an infrastructure itself) blocking infrastructures 
- Military mobility in Europe: infrastructures + customs/technical limits
- Infrastructure as a network 
- Cyber warfare
- Corruption
- Infrastructure crises caused by war
- ‘Evolutionary’ differences of infrastructures in different places
- Infrastructures that arise because of conflict 
- Walls as infrastructure creating separation
- Playful/Ludic infrastructure
- Pop-up walls (temporary or movable barriers)
- Gentrification
- Satellites and the space race 
- Energy

data.title: Biopower
data.desc: Whereas power was once exercised explicitly and performatively (public executions and torture) and manifested in decisions of life or death, today power is directed toward life itself, specifically its control. Infrastructure plays a fundamental role in this.

data.title: Urbicide
data.desc: "Urbicide” is the deliberate destruction of a city or urban environment, targeting its infrastructure, buildings, and social fabric, often to erase its cultural identity or to weaken the community living there.

data.title: War Necropolitics
data.desc: The infrastructure needed to face a war is not accessible to the entire society. It may be necessary to choose who can be saved and who cannot.

data.title: Necropolitics
data.desc: Necropolitics is a concept by the Cameroonian philosopher Achille Mbembe that describes how political power controls people not only through life (biopolitics) but especially through death, determining who lives and who must die.

data.title: The white man's burden
data.desc: A poem by Kipling in which he describes the “duty” of the European man, presenting the construction of infrastructure as a “colonial aid” for “inferior” peoples, which in reality translates into cultural and social domination.

data.title: War targets riorganized for a socio-economical advantage
Energetic Infrastructures
data.desc: Energy infrastructure refers to the systems, facilities, and equipment needed to generate, transmit, store, and distribute energy. These networks keep our homes warm, our factories running, and our cities moving.

data.title: Power Grids
data.desc: Power grid is an infrastructure system that generates, transmits, and distributes electricity from power plants to homes, businesses, and industries. It ensures that electrical energy produced at power stations—such as those using fossil fuels, nuclear power, or renewable sources like wind and solar—can travel long distances and reach consumers safely and reliably.

data.title: Sattelits
data.desc: Satellites like Starlink play a crucial role in warfare, providing Internet access in areas without terrestrial infrastructure. In Ukraine, they support military communications, drone control, and real-time data transmission. They enable operational coordination even in active conflict zones, becoming essential on the battlefield. However, they raise geopolitical and security concerns related to the use of private technology in wars.

data.title: Transportation
data.desc: Transportation infrastructure is the physical network that enables the movement of people and goods, including roads, railways, airports, and canals. It is crucial for economic growth, trade, and social well-being, requiring significant investment and planning to ensure safe, efficient, and sustainable systems.

data.title: In Italy
data.desc: Italy has a well-developed transportation infrastructure with extensive networks of highways and railways, including an operational high-speed rail system that ranks among the longest in the world. The country plays a strategic role in the TEN-T Core Network for the EU market, hosting several European Corridors that connect key industrial clusters, ports, and airports.

data.title: Integration of travel in more facets of life
Environmental sustainability vs developement
data.desc: A socio-political and ecological conflict arises when an infrastructure generates severe environmental impacts or redistributes resources in ways that harm ecosystems and livelihoods, while being presented as a driver of development. The conflict stems from the unequal distribution of costs and benefits and from inadequate decision-making processes and remedies.

data.title: Humanitary/Sanitary help vs war target
data.desc: Hospitals, clinics, ambulances, aid distribution centers, and civilian shelters are attacked or threatened during armed conflicts, despite being designed to protect and save lives.

data.title: Instruction palce vs distruction place
data.desc: Between 2022 and 2023, there were approximately 6,000 attacks on schools and universities worldwide, affecting over 10,000 students and teachers, mainly in Palestine, Ukraine, and the DRC. The attacks, including bombings, arson, and military use of schools, caused prolonged closures, loss of months of education, and severe psychological effects. HRW urges states to adopt the Safe Schools Declaration to protect education during conflicts.

data.title: Turism vs Welfare
data.desc: The way the new forms of overtourism are undermining the welfare of local populations

data.title: La città del sole
data.desc: “La città del Sole” (1602) by Tommaso Campanella is a utopian dialogue that describes an ideal society organized in concentric circles, governed by a priest-philosopher called Sun and his magistrates. In it, there is no private property; everything is shared, even families and children. Education is collective and based on symbols and knowledge painted on the city’s walls. It is a model of harmony between religion, science, and politics, set against the injustices of its time.

data.title: Neuroarchitecture
data.desc: Neuroarchitecture is an interdisciplinary field that combines architecture, neuroscience, psychology, and ergonomics to study how built environments influence the brain, emotions, and human behavior.

data.title: Foreigners everywhere: Biennale
data.desc: Foreigners Everywhere, curated by Brazilian Adriano Pedrosa, was the main art exhibition of the 60th Venice Biennale, which took place from April 20–November 24, 2024. Pedrosa's stated intention for the exhibit was to investigate the idea of living on the margins, whether as an outsider, a new arrival, or an Indigenous person.

data.title: Touristification
data.desc: Touristification is the process by which a city or area becomes dominated by tourism. It often transforms local spaces, services, and culture to cater to visitors. This can lead to economic benefits but also social tensions, displacement, and loss of local identity.

data.title: Luxury tourism
data.desc: Luxury tourism (luxury travel) is a segment of the tourism industry dedicated to travelers seeking unique, personalized, and top-level experiences, prioritizing quality, exclusivity, comfort, privacy, and personal fulfillment.

data.title: Extreme turism
data.desc: Forms of tourism practiced in remote, dangerous contexts beyond the jurisdiction of States, such as the deep sea, polar regions, or outer space.

data.title: Overtourism in Venice
data.desc: The entire physical structure of the city, from its foundations to its canals, is unable to withstand the weight of mass tourism, transforming infrastructure from a resource for residents into a source of conflict.

data.title: Jeff Bezos wedding
data.desc: Jeff Bezos’s wedding in Venice drew huge media attention and an exceptional influx of luxury guests. This kind of event amplifies the problems of elite and mass tourism, which already weigh heavily on the city. Residents experienced mobility issues, with difficult travel and restricted access. Venice thus risks becoming a global stage rather than a livable city for its inhabitants.

data.title: Spacial torusim
data.desc: Blue Origin organizes suborbital tourist flights lasting about 11 minutes, reaching altitudes over 100 km. Passengers experience a few minutes of weightlessness while observing the Earth’s curvature through large panoramic windows. The capsule then returns to Earth with a controlled parachute landing. These missions represent an exclusive form of space tourism, reserved for a select few participants.

data.title: Submarine tourism
data.desc: OceanGate organizes private submarine expeditions to the Titanic wreck, offering participants an exclusive experience aboard the Titan submersible. These missions, lasting about 10 days, cost $250,000 per person, excluding travel expenses to the departure point in Newfoundland, Canada. The business model involved passengers, called “citizen scientists,” participating in scientific research missions, but the company faced criticism over safety and operational transparency. After the fatal Titan incident in June 2023, OceanGate suspended all operations and ceased activities.

data.title: Everest Mount
data.desc: In recent years, extreme tourism on Mount Everest has surged, with thousands of climbers visiting each season. This has caused severe overcrowding, long queues to reach the summit, and increased safety risks. The Nepalese government has responded by raising permit fees and limiting the number of climbers to manage environmental and logistical impacts.

data.title: Politics of infrastructure
data.desc: Social, cultural, and political conflict can arise as early as the planning phase of an infrastructure project. Economic interests, community rights, and cultural heritage may come into conflict. The lack of dialogue fuels protests and delays, while construction often disregards human rights and local cultures.

data.title: Messina Strait Bridge
data.desc: Location: Strait of Messina (Sicily–Calabria, Italy). The project involves national governments, local administrations, construction consortia, environmental groups, and citizens, with disputes over real costs, seismic risks, and potential mafia influence. It has been repeatedly launched, suspended, and restarted. The debate remains constant, balancing promises of development against environmental, technical, and economic concerns.

data.title: No Tav
data.desc: The No TAV movement emerged in Val di Susa against the construction of the Turin–Lyon high-speed rail line. It brings together residents, activists, and social groups denouncing environmental, economic, and social impacts. Conflict with the government and law enforcement has led to protests, clashes, and legal proceedings. It has become a national symbol of resistance against top-down large-scale projects.

data.title: ZAD of Notre Dame des Landes
data.desc: In Notre-Dame-des-Landes, near Nantes, France, local farmers, ZAD ecological activists, the government, and the airport industry clashed over a new airport. Legal questions about occupations versus the right to protest fueled tensions. After decades of mobilization and resistance, strong opposition led to the airport’s cancellation in 2018. The case stands as a notable victory for social movements.

data.title: Vajont Dam
data.desc: Vajont Dam. Date: Catastrophe, October 9, 1963 (Vajont disaster). Location: Erto e Casso / Longarone, Veneto, Italy. Actors: SADE/ENEL and planners, state/regional administrations, local populations; historical ambiguity regarding responsibility and technical omissions (later confirmed by trials). Introduction: During the filling of the reservoir, a gigantic landslide generated a wave that swept away the valleys below, causing nearly 2,000 deaths; a paradigmatic episode of geological underestimation and technocratic decisions without dialogue.

data.title: Dakota Access Pipeline
data.desc: Dakota Access Pipeline (No DAPL / Standing Rock) Date: Main protests April 2016 – February 2017 (but broader impact). Location: North Dakota / routed through multiple US states. Actors: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and other Native tribes, environmental activists, Energy Transfer Partners (proposer), federal government and agencies (Army Corps); ambiguity regarding consultations and respect for historic treaties. Introduction: Global mobilization against pipeline construction near sacred sites and water sources; symbolic episode of the assertion of indigenous rights against energy infrastructure.

data.title: Narita Airport
data.desc: Narita Airport (Sanrizuka struggle, Japan) Date: Conflict from 1966; construction and opening in 1978 (but protests continued). Location: Sanrizuka/Chiba, near Tokyo, Japan. Actors: Farmers and local residents (Sanrizuka), student and leftist groups, Japanese government and police, Narita International Airport Corporation; ambiguity regarding the radicalization of the protests and violence. Introduction: Extremely violent opposition by farmers and leftist groups against expropriations and lack of consultation: occupations, clashes, extreme acts, and years of instability during construction.

data.title: Three Gorges Dam
data.desc: Three Gorges Dam. Date: Main construction 1994–2006; turbines fully operational until 2012. Location: Yangtze, Sandouping (Hubei), China. Stakeholders: Chinese government/China Three Gorges Corp., displaced local populations, environmentalists, scientific community; ambiguity surrounding precise displacement estimates and long-term impacts. Introduction: The world's largest hydroelectric power plant by installed capacity; it has provided flood control and power, but also the displacement of over a million people and the loss of cultural/environmental sites.

data.title: Standard Gauge Railway
data.desc: Standard Gauge Railway (Kenya, Mombasa–Nairobi SGR) Date: Construction and commissioning 2013–2017 (first phase completed 2017). Location: Kenya (Mombasa–Nairobi and branches). Stakeholders: Kenyan government, Chinese companies (CPC/CRBC), port operators, local communities, environmentalists; ambiguity regarding government-to-government contractual terms, debt, and environmental impacts (including on parks). Introduction: Modern line intended to connect the port and the capital; has raised concerns regarding expropriation, land use, impacts on wildlife, and financial sustainability.

data.title: Turkish Dams (GAP and Ilısu)
data.desc: Turkish Dams on the Tigris and Euphrates (GAP/Ilısu - Hasankeyf Projects) Date: GAP project launched in the 1970s; Ilısu and related works active 2006–2020 (impoundment 2019–2020). Location: Southeast Turkey (Turkish Kurdistan), Tigris and Euphrates basins; submerged ancient city of Hasankeyf. Stakeholders: Turkish government (energy and irrigation projects), Kurdish and local communities, archaeologists/international NGOs; ambiguity regarding the balance between water/energy security and heritage protection. Introduction: Part of a broad regional development program (GAP) that has led to expropriations, forced displacement, and the loss of millennia-old sites (Hasankeyf), sparking national and international protests.

data.title: Pan-American Highway / Darien Gap
data.desc: Pan-American Highway / Darien Gap. Data: Road system development began in the 20th century; the Darien Gap remains incomplete (historical strategic absence). Location: From the Americas—a natural gap in the Darién (Panama-Colombia). Stakeholders: National governments, local indigenous communities, environmentalists; ambiguity between commercial connectivity and ecological/indigenous protection interests. Introduction: The decision not to cross the Darién—for technical, environmental, and indigenous protection reasons—has preserved an ecological barrier; it is an example of “missing infrastructure” driven by conflicts and evaluations.

data.title: Narmada Dam and Narmada Bachao Andolan
data.desc: Narmada Dam and Narmada Bachao Andolan (India) Date: Decision-making process and construction from 1960–2000; significant mobilizations from 1985 onwards. Location: Narmada River basin (states of Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Maharashtra), India. Actors: State and central governments, World Bank at some stages, movements led by Medha Patkar/Baba Amte, tribal and peasant communities; ambiguity regarding displacement figures and compensation arrangements. Introduction: A series of large dams (including Sardar Sarovar) that sparked one of India's best-known social resistance movements, echoing issues of development versus indigenous rights.

data.title: Israel–Palestine Separation Wall (West Bank Barrier)
data.desc: Israel–Palestine Separation Wall (West Bank Barrier) Date: Construction began in the early 2000s (after 2002); development and continuous sections. Location: Occupied West Bank territory / de facto borders. Actors: Israeli government, Palestinian authorities and Palestinian populations, international community/NGOs; ambiguity over security rationale vs. impact on rights and political future. Introduction: Barrier defended by Israel as a security measure; denounced by numerous international institutions as a tool that limits freedom of movement and de facto annexes territory.

data.title: Belo Monte Dam
data.desc: Belo Monte Dam (Brazil). Date: Ten-year project phases (since the 1970s); construction intensified in the 2000s; partially operational since 2016. Location: Xingu River, Pará, Amazon, Brazil. Stakeholders: Brazilian government, energy companies, indigenous peoples and local rebels, environmental NGOs; ambiguity regarding the number of displaced people and energy balance vs. ecological impacts. Introduction: One of the most contested hydroelectric projects in the Amazon: large submerged areas, displacement of indigenous communities, and international legal and political battles.

data.title: “Tren (or Tren) Maya” Railway Project
data.desc: “Tren (or Tren) Maya” Railway Project (Mexico). Date: Planning and construction start 2018–2023; sections partially opened/operational from 2023. Location: Yucatán Peninsula (states: Quintana Roo, Yucatán, Campeche, Tabasco, Chiapas). Stakeholders: Mexican government (AMLO), construction companies, indigenous Mayan communities, environmentalists, scientists/UNESCO; ambiguity regarding effective consultation and damage to biospheres/karst cavities. Introduction: A major tourism and regional development project that has sparked protests over environmental impacts, expropriation, and the failure to protect archaeological sites and local communities.

data.title: HS2 High-Speed ​​Rail
data.desc: HS2 High-Speed ​​Rail (UK). Date: Project approved in the 2010s; intense construction and protests, especially from 2017–2024 (and beyond). Location: Great Britain (London → Midlands → North). Actors: UK government, construction companies, local communities and environmental groups (tree activists, anti-HS2 camps), local authorities; ambiguity over economic benefits vs. destruction of forests/landscapes. Introduction: Project intended to connect regions and “balance” the country; has met with strong opposition due to its impact on ancient forests, costs, and long-term benefits.

data.title: Montalto di Castro Nuclear Power Plant
data.desc: Montalto di Castro Nuclear Power Plant (Italy). Date: Construction began 1982; halted after 1987 referendum (Chernobyl → political decision) — never entered into operation. Location: Montalto di Castro, Lazio, Italy. Actors: ENEL (proponent), government, anti-nuclear movements, public opinion (referendum); ambiguity over economic losses vs. post-Chernobyl democratic choice. Introduction: Nearing completion, the plant was halted by the national referendum that ended Italy's nuclear expansion in the 1980s; an exemplary case of direct democracy blocking an infrastructure.

data.title: Suez Canal
data.desc: Suez Canal (19th century). Date: Construction 1859–1869; inauguration November 17, 1869. Location: Isthmus of Suez, Egypt. Actors: European companies (Ferdinand de Lesseps / Compagnie universelle du canal), Egyptian authorities (viceroy), local forced laborers (corvée), colonial powers; historical ambiguity regarding actual deaths and working conditions (estimates vary). Introduction: A work that revolutionized global maritime trade; built with strong European intervention and the use of massive labor, sources differ on human losses and social cost.

data.title: Aswan High Dam
data.desc: Aswan High Dam (Egypt). Date: Construction 1960–1970 (completion 1970; filling and operation until the 1970s). Location: Aswan, Egypt (Nile). Actors: Egyptian government (Nasser), Soviet Union (support/funding), displaced Nubian populations, scientific communities, and UNESCO (Abu Simbel rescue); ambiguity over economic benefits vs. cultural loss and environmental impacts. Introduction: A national project symbolizing modernization (power and flood control) that solved many water issues but resulted in the relocation of tens of thousands of Nubians and the submergence of historic sites (international archaeological rescues).

data.title: Atatürk Airport / New Istanbul Airport (Turkey).
data.desc: Atatürk Airport / New Istanbul Airport (Turkey). Date: New airport project started 2010s; opening and relocation 2018; protests documented primarily 2017–2018. Location: Istanbul, Turkey. Actors: Turkish government (major state project), construction companies, workers (complaints about conditions), unions, and NGOs; ambiguity about actual number of accidents/deaths and transparency. Introduction: The new airport has become a symbol of modernization but also of human costs (rapid working conditions, reported fatalities) and deforestation.

data.title: Trans-Amazonian Highway (BR-230, Brazil)
data.desc: Trans-Amazonian Highway (BR-230, Brazil). Date: Construction early 1970s (military regime), subsequent expansions; incomplete and amplifying deforestation. Location: Brazilian Amazon (various portions of BR-230). Actors: Brazilian military government, settlers, agribusiness/mining companies, indigenous peoples, environmentalists; ambiguity between development slogans and actual environmental impacts. Introduction: Colonial initiative to open up the Amazon that fueled waves of deforestation, settlements, and conflicts with indigenous peoples; symbol of an infrastructure that transformed the territory.

data.title: Guatemala Highway Corridor (CA-9 and related projects)
data.desc: Guatemala Highway Corridor (CA-9 and related projects). Date: Various projects and construction over the past decades; recurring tensions (blockades and protests, especially 2010s–2020s). Location: Guatemala (port-inland connections). Actors: Guatemalan government, infrastructure companies, indigenous communities (Maya), social movements and land defense; ambiguity regarding consultation and respect for collective rights. Introduction: Connectivity projects often cross indigenous territories without adequate consultation: communities have organized blockades, assemblies, and protests to demand the right to consultation and land.

data.title: San Vittore Prison
data.desc:
Infrastructure= prisons, facilities for managing social issues

Conflict = the infrastructure itself is the conflict (often invisible, prisons are located in hidden locations; it is a mirror of a dysfunctional society, which few, however, want to address).

Structural failure: social structure that, rather than managing the problem, becomes a catalyst for crisis (overcrowding at 247%, the facility can no longer guarantee humane living conditions).

Isolation: lack of human resources to support the maintenance and health of inmates + lack of bureaucracy

data.title: Pruitt-Igoe residential complex
data.desc:
The Pruitt–Igoe complex was a massive public housing project in St. Louis, Missouri, designed by architect Minoru Yamasaki and completed in 1955. It consisted of 33 eleven-story high-rise buildings with nearly 3,000 apartments, intended to provide modern, affordable housing for low-income residents after World War II.

Initially celebrated as a symbol of urban renewal, Pruitt–Igoe soon faced serious problems, including poor maintenance, crime, poverty, and social isolation, worsened by inadequate funding and flawed design. By the late 1960s, many units were abandoned, and the complex became a national example of failed public housing policy. Beginning in 1972, the buildings were systematically demolished, marking one of the most famous collapses of modernist architecture and urban planning ideals in the United States.

data.title: Hulme Crescents Notorious residential complex
data.desc:
The Hulme Crescents were a vast public housing development in Manchester, England, completed in 1972 as part of a postwar urban renewal plan. Consisting of four massive curved concrete blocks with deck-access walkways, they were intended to provide modern, affordable homes inspired by the elegance of Georgian architecture.

Despite their ambitious design, the Crescents quickly suffered from poor construction, damp, heating problems, and rising crime, while their elevated walkways created isolation and safety concerns. Within just a few years many residents demanded rehousing, and the complex gained a reputation for neglect and danger. By the early 1990s the buildings were largely abandoned, and between 1993 and 1995 the entire development was demolished, becoming a symbol of failed modernist housing policy in the UK.

data.title: Common critical point in infrastructural projects
data.desc:
FUNCTION – Expression of intent by individuals or authorities that can create conflicts of interest within society.

PLANNING – Organizational problems, such as the urgent need for a facility that cannot be built in time.

DESIGN – Architectural choices that clash with the intended function, for example buildings poorly suited to their environment or use.

CONSTRUCTION – Environmental and social issues related to the location or size of the infrastructure.

USE – A gap between the project’s concept and its realization, leaving users dissatisfied.

DEGRADATION – Abandonment and disuse of infrastructures, leading to wasted resources.

data.title: Grenfell Tower (London, 2017)
data.desc:
Grenfell Tower (London, 2017)

Problem: Fire caused by combustible cladding, resulting in 72 deaths.

Psychological effects: Survivors and residents of nearby blocks reported post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, insomnia, and fire-related phobias.

Legal relevance: The UK government recognized the need for long-term psychological support for former residents.

data.title: Citicorp Center (New York, 1970s)
data.desc:
Citicorp Center (New York, 1970s)

Problem: It was discovered that the building could collapse in the event of strong winds.

Psychological effects: When the news became public, tenants reported chronic anxiety and fear of working on the upper floors—even after repairs.

data.title: John Hancock Tower (Boston, 1970s)
data.desc:
John Hancock Tower (Boston, 1970s)

Problem: Glass panels detached and fell.

Psychological effects: Workers and passersby spoke of “constant terror” and “killer glass panic,” and many avoided walking beneath the building.

data.title: Infrastructural limits
data.desc:
Infrastructure becomes a means and place for bureaucratic decisions

Like
Accessibility to hospitals
Accessibility to bunkers
Accessibility to prisons

data.title: Infrastructures that feed social conflict
data.desc:
Infrastructure, depending on how and where it is built, can create or accentuate social conflict by increasing social isolation, discrimination, poverty, and crime.
This phenomenon often occurs with spatial renewal policies, such as those in Scampia, Pruitt-Igoe, and Hulme Crescents

data.title: Infrastructures that increase war conflict
data.desc:
These are infrastructures that are built specifically for war or infrastructures that, if manipulated, can be used as a weapon fueling conflict.
Such as
Trade routes (e.g., the Silk Road, tariffs, etc.)
Gas in Russia
Tariffs as an economic logistics infrastructure
Arms trafficking fuels wars
Soldier transportation
Food transportation

data.title: Grim milestone on World Humanitarian Day
data.desc:
WHO records 1940 attacks on healthcare in Ukraine since the start of full-scale war.
→ Systematic data on attacks on healthcare facilities, their impact on primary and secondary services, and consequences for patients and medical staff. Useful for documenting the phenomenon of healthcare attacks as a war strategy/effect.

data.title: Russian attacks on Ukraine power grid
data.desc:
Russian attacks on Ukraine power grid likely violate humanitarian law, says UN
→ The UN has declared that repeated Russian attacks on Ukraine's power grid between March and August 2024 likely violate international humanitarian law. The attacks on energy infrastructure have left entire cities without power, compromising water, heating, and essential services. Blackouts of up to 18 hours a day are expected. Kiev and its allies consider them war crimes, while Moscow maintains they are legitimate military targets.

data.title: EU: Russian gas phase-out, end of imports by 2027
data.desc:
→ The EU wants to reduce dependence on Russian gas: starting in 2026, a halt to new contracts and the use of LNG terminals for Russian customers, and from 2028, long-term contracts. Each country will have to plan alternatives to avoid energy crises. But the construction of new infrastructure creates tensions: local protests, conflicts between states, and a clash between energy security and ecological transition.

Gas pipelines such as Nord Stream 1 and 2 have made Europe dependent on Russian supplies for approximately 40% of its gas needs, giving Russia bargaining and political power over it.

data.title: Yemen's water situation
data.desc: Yemen faces a severe water crisis: war, poor infrastructure, and excessive consumption for qat cultivation have drastically reduced access to drinking water. The lack of safe water has led to epidemics, such as cholera. The ICRC is responding by repairing wells and water networks, distributing water and treatment supplies, and supporting millions of people each year.

data.title: Conflict Resilience of Water and Energy Supply Infrastructure: Insights from Yemen
data.desc: → Examines the resilience of water and energy infrastructure in Yemen during the armed conflict that began in 2015. It analyzes the adaptive responses of communities and public institutions to disruptions and shortages in the water and energy sectors, critically assessing these responses from the perspective of infrastructure resilience in conflict contexts.
